Another interesting point that was brought up this week, this from a conference that was sponsored by American Enterprise Institute, and it actually took a look at philanthropy as relates to schools.
And it's suggesting that the new benefactors, those that are giving today, are less likely to hand out mega donations, large donations, and let the system take over instead.
They are insisting that schools improve test scores, in many cases overhaul basic functions.
And there has been some concern that these benefactors may also start to shape curriculum and move into other areas that perhaps, perhaps I underline, should be left to the schools.
Laura, how much does the idea of the mighty dollar come into play here?
The dollar always talks.
This is a longtri--term trend in terms of the school reform movement in general.
Obviously, No Child Left Behind--there's been a lot of calling and pressure for more accountability, more responsibility, and I don't see anything wrong with that on its face.
I do have a concern, though, about the influence that philanthropy can have.
I've seen it here in Chicago.
The major foundations here have a lot of influence over government.
They're funding a lot of gover--programs that norm--that used to be supported by government in terms of rehabilitation of public housing, in terms of school reform, in terms of many other issues.
And the dollars talk.

The point that has been made, though, is that the--I guess, the amount of money overall that's going from major philanthropy into education is like $1.5 billion annually, and that's small fry as compared with the $400-some billion that comes from government.
George Curry, they're also suggesting that these benefactors are also guiding and rethinking how superintendents and school boards are trained.
Ofttimes these school boards and superintendents are elected by voters within states.
How much does this cross a line?
Well, I mean, conservative foundations have been extremely interested in higher education and been giving them money.
Certainly slanted in that direction.
I think this can be a good thing if properly used.
I was speaking to the council on--urban board of education--board--boards out in San Diego recently.
And what--I found out there were a lot of creative things going on in public education with the help of foundations.
For example, in Chattanooga, they matched their best performing teachers with their worst performing schools and they give the teachers a $5,000 bonus.
If the schools advance a certain level, they give them $2,000.
If they want to buy a home in the city, they give them a partial down payment.
There are creative ways that we can improve our public school system, and I think that's where the emphasis ought to be and I think they can play an important role.
